relationships.evidence_text: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron Perry.
And today we're visiting with Lem Tingley, the CEO and CGO of growing spaces.
he fell in love with the Rocky Mountain West at an early age.
He attended the University of Colorado in Boulder and graduated with a degree in mechanical engineering.
which led to working for the last 25 years in manufacturing both in Colorado and offshore.
Lem is married to his wife Liz.
they live in Golden Colorado with their three teenage boys.
he was laid off from his previous job in engineering.
Lem and Liz jumped on it. And they immediately came down to Pugosa Springs... purchased growing spaces in April of 2018.
having heard of growing spaces through his brother-in-law.
to meet Udgar and Pugia Parsons.
you'll get to see a little interview with them later on the founders.
they fell in love with them and what they had created in this small town in Colorado.
are now expanding the company organically.
Lem grew up outside Boston, Massachusetts.
came to Colorado every year as a kid for ski vacations.
I was a big skier growing up back east.
my parents talked me into visiting seeing Boulder on the way back to the airport.
graduated with a degree in mechanical engineering.
I'm so interested to hear more about your engineering background and how you're going to apply that.
how you're helping people in communities all over grow a lot more food.
to either start or purchase a company in some sort of sustainable technology.
they live in Golden Colorado with their three teenage boys.
Lem grew up outside Boston, Massachusetts.
having heard of growing spaces through his brother-in-law.
purchased growing spaces in April of 2018.
are now expanding the company organically.
I love hiking and biking and all that.
never moved out of Colorado since since I was 18.
Growing spaces has six different sizes domes that we sell.
Later today I'll show you some 42-foot domes that we have down at the geothermal partnership.
we're currently in the 33-foot diameter dome which is our second biggest size.
We're here in Pagosta Springs.
we've shipped probably about 3,000 domes to all 50 states, about 15 countries across the globe.
about half our sales are here in Colorado because of the extreme weather.
the Buckminster Fuller dome really is good against the wind.
the shape of the geodesic dome... really just pushes the dome back down into the earth.
the real value of it is it tracks the sun all day long.
we will visit with one of your gardeners and educators Heather Gray talking about soil.
they're building a 42-foot dome for their students.
